How to Escape a Wrist Grab
Learn the basic technique to break free from an attacker\'s grip. The key is to twist toward the thumb - the weakest part of their grip. This simple move can buy you crucial seconds to escape.
Stay calm and don\'t panic when grabbed
Identify where their thumb is positioned
Rotate your wrist sharply toward their thumb
Pull away forcefully and run to safety immediately
If you must defend yourself, aim for areas that cause maximum impact with minimal force. These pressure points can disable an attacker long enough for you to escape safely.
Eyes: Use fingers to poke or rake across attacker\'s eyes
Nose: Strike upward with palm heel to break nose
Throat: Jab with stiff fingers to the Adam\'s apple
Groin: Knee or kick forcefully to disable attacker
Knees: Kick to break kneecap and prevent pursuit
Always be prepared with these legal self-defense tools. Keep them easily accessible but concealed. Practice using them so you can react quickly in an emergency.
Pepper spray: Legal and effective, aim for eyes and mouth
Loud whistle: Attracts attention and startles attackers
Personal alarm: 120dB+ sound to disorient and alert others
Keys between fingers: Makeshift weapon for close combat
Most attacks can be prevented by staying vigilant. Trust your instincts - if something feels wrong, it probably is. Confidence and awareness are your best defense.
Cybercriminals use fake emails, texts, and websites to steal your personal information. Never click suspicious links or download attachments from unknown sources. When in doubt, verify directly.
Check sender email address carefully for misspellings
Hover over links to see actual destination before clicking
Never share passwords or OTPs via email or SMS
Enable 2FA on all important accounts (banking, email, social media)
Oversharing on social media makes you a target for criminals and stalkers. Limit what strangers can see about your life, location, and daily routines.
Review and tighten privacy settings on all platforms
Turn off location sharing for posts and stories
Don\'t post real-time locations or travel plans
Only accept friend requests from people you know personally
Protect yourself from malware and identity theft by being cautious online. Use secure connections, especially for banking and shopping.
Use built-in safety features of Ola, Uber, and other ride-sharing apps. Always verify the driver and vehicle before getting in. Trust your instincts if something feels wrong.
Share trip details with trusted contacts before starting
Know how to use in-app SOS and emergency buttons
Sit behind the driver, not in the front passenger seat
Keep emergency contacts easily accessible on your phone
Whether in public transport, workplace, or streets, know how to respond to harassment effectively. Your safety is the priority - be loud, be seen, get help.
Speak loudly and firmly: \'STOP! LEAVE ME ALONE!\'
Move towards crowds, well-lit areas, or authorities
Yell \'FIRE\' instead of \'HELP\' - people respond faster
In potentially unsafe situations, prioritize mobility over fashion. Wear clothes and shoes that allow you to run or defend yourself if needed.
Extra caution is needed after dark. Plan your route, stay in well-lit areas, and always let someone know your whereabouts. Your confidence and awareness can deter potential threats.
Plan your route in advance using well-lit main roads
Avoid shortcuts through dark alleys or isolated areas
Walk with purpose and confidence - scan your surroundings
Use phone flashlight in dimly lit areas
When using buses, trains, or metro at night, choose your seats wisely and stay alert. Inform someone about your travel plans and expected arrival time.
Memorize these crucial numbers and program them into your phone\'s speed dial. In an emergency, every second counts. These are free to call from any network.
Set Up ICE (In Case of Emergency) Contacts
ICE contacts help first responders reach your family in emergencies. Set them up in your phone\'s emergency contact section and on your lock screen.
Choose Safe Seating in Public Transport
Strategic seating can prevent harassment and ensure quick exit in emergencies. Sit near exits, drivers, or conductors when possible.
Keep your belongings secure and stay aware of your surroundings. Don\'t fall asleep or get too distracted by your phone during long journeys.
Your home should be your safest space. Use proper locks, verify visitors, and have emergency procedures in place for all family members.
Never open your door to strangers without proper verification. Use peepholes, intercoms, or ask for identification through the closed door.
Know your rights and reporting procedures. Document incidents and report to HR or authorities immediately. Your workplace should be safe and respectful.
Familiarize yourself with campus security, emergency phones, and safe routes. Use the buddy system, especially during late hours.
Learn to say NO firmly and remove yourself from uncomfortable situations. Trust your instincts about people and situations that feel wrong.
Learn to identify gaslighting, guilt-tripping, and other manipulation tactics. If someone constantly makes you doubt yourself, seek outside perspective.
During an earthquake, DROP to your hands and knees, take COVER under a sturdy desk or table, and HOLD ON until the shaking stops. Stay away from windows and heavy objects.
In case of fire, get low to avoid smoke, feel doors before opening, and exit immediately. Never use elevators during a fire emergency.
In a stampede, stay on your feet, move with the crowd (not against it), and protect your chest with your arms in a boxer\'s stance. Look for gaps to escape.
Teach children never to go with strangers, even if they claim to know their parents. Identify safe adults they can approach if scared or lost.
Monitor children\'s internet use, enable parental controls, and teach them never to share personal information or meet online friends without approval.
Learn basic first aid to help others and yourself in emergencies. Keep a first aid kit at home and in your car with essential supplies.
If someone is unresponsive and not breathing, begin chest compressions (100-120 per minute) and rescue breaths until help arrives. Consider taking a certified CPR course.
Install grab bars, remove tripping hazards, use night lights, and consider medical alert systems. Regular check-ins with family or neighbors are important.
Be wary of unsolicited calls, emails, or visits asking for personal information. If an offer sounds too good to be true, it probably is.
Connect with trusted queer-friendly spaces and support networks. When meeting new people, choose public venues and inform trusted friends about your plans.
Familiarize yourself with LGBTQ+ helplines and support organizations. Know your rights - harassment based on sexual orientation or gender identity is illegal.
Share your itinerary with someone, get local SIM cards, download offline maps, and research cultural norms. Don\'t reveal you\'re traveling alone to strangers.
Choose well-reviewed accommodations in safe areas. Check security features like proper locks, well-lit entrances, and 24-hour reception.
Know your rights under Indian law. Police must register FIRs for crimes against women immediately. You\'re entitled to protection and support from authorities.
Report online harassment, stalking, or fraud to the National Cyber Crime Reporting Portal (cybercrime.gov.in) or local cyber police stations.
Your gut feeling is often right. If a person, place, or situation makes you uncomfortable, remove yourself immediately. It\'s better to be rude than unsafe.
Never disclose personal details like your address, when you\'re home alone, or that you\'re new to an area. Act confident and familiar with your surroundings even when you\'re not.
Keep your phone charged, inform trusted contacts about your whereabouts, and establish check-in times. Use location sharing with trusted family or friends when traveling.
Download and familiarize yourself with safety apps like Himmat Plus (Delhi), SafetiPin, bSafe, and your state\'s women safety app. Keep them easily accessible.
